data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Industry expert calls for urgent resuscitation of SA’s gold sector Nokukhanya Mntambo Nokukhanya Mntambo 6 February 2026 | 7:52 While South Africa is still among the big players in the global gold market, the country has been surpassed by a number of countries, including China and Ghana. Gold mine collapse Gold Lily Mine Industry expert calls for urgent resuscitation of SA’s gold sector Lily Mine in Barberton, near Mpumalanga. Picture: Sphamandla Dlamini/EWN Senior gold industry executive and CEO of Lions Bay Resources, Lloyd Birrell, believes urgent interventions are needed to pull back the decline in the country’s gold mining industry. While South Africa is still among the big players in the global gold market, the country has been surpassed by a number of countries, including China and Ghana. Mining in South Africa faces increasing challenges, including declining ore grades and increasing operational costs affecting the bottom line. Calls for lower electricity costs are among the demands from miners squeezed by prices. According to Mining Weekly, local gold production has been shrinking at an average rate of 5.8% a year since 1994, falling from 580 tonnes to less than 90 tonnes in 2024. Last year, China’s production of the precious metal was almost four times South Africa’s production. Although gold prices have come down from the January 29 highs, the precious metal surpassed the $5, 500 mark per ounce this year. Birrell explained: “It’s extraordinary that at a gold price like this, South Africa’s gold mining has declined to the extent that it has.” Birrell’s Lions Bay Resources is among the interested bidders for the derelict Lily Gold mine near Barberton after its 2016 closure. But the process to get the mine out of business rescue remains stalled by a series of litigations. Lily Mine is the site of the 2016 tragedy where three mineworkers were trapped underground in a container following a fall of ground accident. Their remains were never retrieved. Birrell was among those at the mine on Thursday, where the families of Pretty Nkambule, Yvonne Mnisi and Solomon Nyirenda marked the 10th anniversary of the tragedy. He believes his firm has the capital and expertise to revive the now-flooded Lily Mine, which is a complex and technical process. “Now, our plan is, because we know what the disadvantages or the difficulties with Lily are, is that we would open Brookbrook, and we could use all the infrastructure and the deposition available. We would be operating underground in Barbrook within nine months. We have the capacity and the operation, operational capacity, and the plant is there. We can do it in nine months. So, we can catch up some time, and then we can, then we can spend the next three years dewatering and reestablishing lily, said Birrell.”

data.content: The Newcastle Cogeneration CPR update would align quite nicely to this before Indaba too...

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Fascinating timing just a few days before Indaba 2026 nothing like a bit of ESG angle to speed up DMRE engagement and BRP decisions Mining experts flag looming environmental challenges at Lily Mine Nokukhanya Mntambo 6 February 2026 | 4:31 The mine shut its doors in 2016 after a deadly structural collapse. Lily Mine Mining experts flag looming environmental challenges at Lily Mine A gate leading at the Lily Mine near Baberton, in Mpumalanga, leading to the scene where victims Pretty Nkambule, Solomon Nyirenda and Yvonne Mnisi were trapped underground a decade ago. Picture: Sphamandla Dlamini/EWN Some mining experts have raised concerns about the looming environmental challenges of the now-derelict Lily gold mine near Barberton, in Mpumalanga. The mine shut its doors in 2016 after a deadly structural collapse. Pretty Nkambule, Solomon Nyirenda and Yvonne Mnisi were trapped underground a decade ago following the collapse of Lily Mine. Their bodies were never recovered. ALSO READ: Potential Lily Mine investors: Red tape hampers Efforts to resume operations The senior gold industry executive and CEO of Lions Bay Resources, Lloyd Birrell, said flooding in the Lily gold mine could have a spillover effect on the agriculture downstream if the water makes its way into the irrigation canal. “The difficulty is that when water collects in a mine, a chemical process then takes place. Eventually, the water changes its pH. It can become extremely low, which means it's acidic, which means it dissolves other metals, like arsenic or manganese or, for example, nickel. These are not good things to have dissolved in the water.” He said it also has a damaging effect for the local community. “Now the community doesn't have safe drinking water anymore, and what we need to ascertain is whether or not that is caused by the huge volume of water sitting underground, which is mutating, either becoming excessively alkaline and with a low pH, which is not a good, not a good combination. So, there is a significant environmental component to reopening this mine.”

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Fell CUR (Current Price) is the reference price the market displays as “the price” at any given moment, but it only updates when a trade is allowed to go through the lit order book in a way that qualifies as price-forming. Large trades done off-book, negotiated crosses, or internalised trades can change ownership without moving CUR at all. So CUR can be held still for long periods even while substantial volume trades elsewhere, making it look quiet or weak to retail — when in reality liquidity is being absorbed or redistributed behind the scenes.

data.content: Fell A lot of 250k trades going through as late reported and hard to judge on many of them if they went through bid or offer side.  The majority of trades going threw off book (like yesterday) which meant CUR was stuck for hours. The main difference today is that we seem to be trading in a slightly higher band (for now) 1.98 - 2.1 rather than 1.91 - 1.98 in the main. It seems to have held the higher trading band for longer today, although if it does what it did yesterday it might weaken to EOP

data.content: You could argue that across North America, governments are starting to treat old mine waste and tailings less as environmental problems and more as useful resources that can be cleaned up and reused. This does fit neatly with national-security goals around securing domestic supplies of critical minerals like uranium and vanadium. Canada has already shown that reprocessing old waste can be permitted faster and supported by public policy, and the US is now applying similar thinking through frameworks linked to NISA of which we obviously have agreements with on the Uranium side.  Companies like Fulcrum are literally playing into that Narrative. And in turn, the potential of short term revenue etc etc etc

data.author: andymlloyd
data.content: Another cracker of an RNS, if you read between the lines. MET1 have just upped their stake in Fulcrum Metals (FMET) to 6.33% by exercising warrants at 5p — not selling, not trimming… doubling down. This tells us: Initial £175k investment is now up over 100% (unrealised) FMET share price has more than doubled in ~6 months MET1 are confident enough to: Increase exposure now Take new warrants at 10p valid for 18 months (i.e. expecting much higher prices ahead) This isn’t retail punt behaviour, this is strategic capital allocation. And Fulcrum isn’t just another junior either: Cyanide-free metal recovery (ESG box ticked ) Reprocessing mine tailings (low capex, high margin potential) Canada-based projects (Teck-Hughes & Sylvanite) Using proven tech from Extrakt Process Solutions Read the MD quote carefully, he’s basically telling you: Progress is real, price action is justified, and the next stage is coming. Meanwhile MET1 holders get: NAV uplift Exposure to a second critical metals story Optionality via 10p warrants Proof management can pick winners and monetise early For a company that’s still massively undervalued on its own projects, this is exactly the sort of RNS that often gets ignored, right before the market wakes up. DYOR (Be Nice to Each Other, Cue the Muppets)

data.author: andymlloyd
data.content: MET1 quietly executing the smart money playbook here 👀 Just offloaded 7.5m CTL shares for £745k at ~100% profit and still holding 12.85m shares (6.33% stake) PLUS 20m warrants to 2030 at 6p. That’s textbook portfolio management; take profit into demand, keep massive upside exposure. Exactly what you want from a strategic metals investment vehicle. CTL pushing towards Final Investment Decision in Chile and MET1 still fully leveraged to success, but now with extra cash in the bank. This shows MET1 isn’t just drilling holes, they’re actively managing capital like a mini fund, rotating winners while keeping moon shot optionality. Lithium cycle hasn’t even started properly yet. When sentiment flips, having equity + long-dated warrants could be explosive. Smart management, de-risking, and still huge upside. MCAP vs portfolio value starting to look silly. DYOR (Be Nice to Each Other, Cue the Nuggets)

data.author: i-man
data.content: Metals One acquired approximately 19–20% of Lions Bay Capital Inc., a Canadian-listed mining finance company. This investment was made through: A C$750,000 subscription for 7.5 million Lions Bay shares. A later strategic investment of up to US$1.8 million in Lions Bay Resources (a South African private company jointly owned by Lions Bay Capital and Salamander Mining). What the Lions Bay Project Actually Is Lions Bay’s priority project is reviving a gold processing plant in South Africa, which previously shut down in 2021 after only 18 months of operation. The plant is expected to be back in production by Q4 2026, offering near‑term cash flow potential. Lions Bay holds an option to acquire the plant’s cogeneration facility for US$1.4 million, which originally cost around US$20 million to build. Metals One sees the project as: A low‑cost entry into gold production through a partner rather than direct mine development. A way to balance its portfolio, which includes earlier‑stage uranium and critical metals exploration. An opportunity to gain exposure to South African gold assets managed by experienced operators, including former executives from major gold companies. Metals One is not developing a gold mine itself in Africa. Instead, it has taken a significant minority stake in Lions Bay Capital and Lions Bay Resources to support and benefit from the restart of a South African gold processing plant, expected to generate cash flow in the near term.

data.author: LaGomera
data.content: Wise and succinct words from "allforprofit", but before anyone posts a response, there are one or two exceptions. However, cast your minds back to the extensive hype that propelled the price; the changing prospects; the discounted fundraising.  How frequently do investors in high risk minnows see this? Dream on, ye delusionists, who ooze confidence that multi-£ market share prices will ensue.  None comment upon the wider mining market or the merger talks involving RTZ. "allforprofits'" wise words should be heeded, and, might I add, whilst there is enjoyment to be had from investing in more speculative shares, only invest what you are prepared to write-off, the nano-second after you have parted with your money. Expert VC's expect to not make money from most of their investments, but to do so well from one or two of the "good-uns" that they can boast returns on their portfolio. Enjoy the weekend and best wishes to all.

data.author: Laura2022
data.content: Recently SAV got over €100mln from Portugal Daniel Maling, Managing Director of Metals One, commented: "Access to raw materials is essential for the EU's economy and the functioning of the internal market. The Black Schist Project is a multi-metal extraction project potentially contributing to the Union's security of supply for several Strategic Raw Materials. Strategic Project designation would provide several key advantages that could aid in the project's development and long-term success, including but not limited to enhanced access to project financing, including eligibility for funding from EU programmes, and streamlined permitting processes. Given the key role of many critical raw materials in realising the green and digital transitions, and considering their use for defence and aerospace applications, demand is likely to increase exponentially in the coming decades. Further, risk of supply disruptions is increasing against the background of rising geopolitical tensions and resource competition. We believe our Black Schist Project can contribute a stable and secure resource of strategic and critical metals to the EU market."

data.author: andymlloyd
data.content: MET1 quietly executing the smart money playbook here 👀 Just offloaded 7.5m CTL shares for £745k at ~100% profit and still holding 12.85m shares (6.33% stake) PLUS 20m warrants to 2030 at 6p. That’s textbook portfolio management; take profit into demand, keep massive upside exposure. Exactly what you want from a strategic metals investment vehicle. CTL pushing towards Final Investment Decision in Chile and MET1 still fully leveraged to success, but now with extra cash in the bank. This shows MET1 isn’t just drilling holes, they’re actively managing capital like a mini fund, rotating winners while keeping moon shot optionality. Lithium cycle hasn’t even started properly yet. When sentiment flips, having equity + long-dated warrants could be explosive. Smart management, de-risking, and still huge upside. MCAP vs portfolio value starting to look silly. data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (AIM:MET1) completed significant fundraisings in 2025, raising over £15 million to diversify into high-potential gold and uranium projects alongside their existing battery metal assets. While the company is positioned for growth with a strengthened portfolio, analysts suggest recovery to previous highs is heavily dependent on resource validation, project development, and sustained high commodity prices. Key Findings for 2025-2026: Strategic Transformation: In April 2025, the company secured funding to expand its portfolio, focusing on copper and uranium to complement its existing nickel projects. Market Conditions: The firm aimed to leverage record-high gold and commodity prices to drive value. Performance: Despite potential, the stock experienced volatility, falling 80% from a 52-week high in mid-2025, but was actively looking to recover through new acquisitions in Finland, Norway, and the USA. Outlook: As of late 2025, the firm was focused on drilling and developing these new, high-impact projects to drive long-term value. The company's success relies on whether its newly acquired projects can deliver on their projected value to boost share price.

data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (MET1) has shown capacity to attract institutional support, particularly during capital raises for its battery metal projects in Europe, though it remains a high-risk, high-reward, small-cap, pre-revenue entity. Based on 2025 and early 2026 data, here is an analysis of Metals One's appeal to institutional investors: Factors Attracting Institutional Investors: Strategic Assets in Favorable Locations: Metals One operates in Finland (Black Schist Project) and Norway (Råna Project), jurisdictions with strong local demand for EV battery materials (nickel, copper, cobalt) and favorable mining regulations. Support During Fundraising: The company has successfully secured funding with "institutional and retail backing," such as the £3.1 million equity raise in April 2025 to fund project development. Industry Focus: The company’s focus on critical metals for the energy transition aligns with thematic investing trends, making it attractive to specialized natural resource funds. Partnerships and Growth: The company has initiated strategic investments and acquisitions (e.g., in Fidelity Minerals Corp and CleanTech Lithium), which can attract institutional attention.

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: For anyone following MET1’s US uranium exposure, it’s worth independently researching why BHP has pulled the Utah Geological Survey into its Xplor program, and what that signals about how major miners now approach early-stage discovery. This isn’t about individual projects being “picked”; it’s about district-scale mineral systems being re-evaluated — and companies already embedded in those systems arguably  stand to benefit first. BHP’s inclusion of the Utah Geological Survey reflects a clear shift toward regional mineral-systems thinking, authoritative public-domain data, and modern reinterpretation of historic geology before capital-intensive drilling. UGS’ role focuses on state-wide and regional geological frameworks — integrating historic datasets, modern geophysics, and targeted fieldwork — rather than endorsing individual projects, and that work informs understanding of sediment-hosted uranium-vanadium systems across Utah and the wider Colorado Plateau margin. In that context, MET1’s Vanadium King Project in Utah sits within the Uravan Mineral Belt and is hosted in the same sandstone unit that underpins multiple historic uranium-vanadium deposits across the region. While the host horizon itself is continuous, higher-grade mineralisation occurs in localised zones rather than as a uniform sheet, which is normal for this deposit style. Historic drilling and workings at Vanadium King intersected uranium and vanadium at the correct geological level, confirming the presence of a proven regional system rather than an isolated occurrence. Academic and public-domain studies across the Uravan Belt show this type of mineralisation to be predictable when viewed at system level, even though grades vary from place to place. As state-level geological frameworks are modernised and published, projects already positioned within validated systems — such as MET1’s Uravan Belt assets — can possibly gain strategic relevance without forcing near-term drilling or promotional noise? Thoughts?

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: In 2025, Metals One PLC (AIM: MET1) announced the acquisition of the Hammaslahti and Outokumpu copper projects in Finland from 80 Mile PLC. Located in Eastern Finland, these projects include high-potential exploration targets associated with former, high-grade copper mines. However, by July 2025, Metals One decided not to proceed with this acquisition, shifting focus to US-based critical minerals.
data.thread_title: RE: Step By Step but moving forward nicely

data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (AIM: MET1) is primarily an exploration and development company, with its investment, Evolution Energy Minerals (16.9% stake), targeting first ore production at the Chilalo Graphite Project by October 2027. The company focuses on developing projects in Finland and the U.S., rather than immediate direct production. Key Production and Development Timelines: Chilalo Graphite Project (via Evolution): Accelerated development schedule aims for first ore mining by October 2027. Hammaslahti/Outokumpu Projects (Finland): Following 2025 acquisitions and drilling, the company is focused on resource expansion. U.S. Uranium/Vanadium Projects: Acquisitions in Colorado/Utah were completed in 2025, targeting exploration rather than immediate production. Metals One operates as an investor/developer, aiming to build a portfolio of assets to supply critical minerals to Western markets.

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Lions Bay Mining (Pty) Ltd – new SA entity worth noting? Quick heads-up for those tracking the Lions Bay / MET1 / Vantage situation. A new South African company, Lions Bay Mining (Pty) Ltd (Enterprise No. K2026004873), was incorporated on 6 January 2026 and is currently active. Key points: Jurisdiction: South Africa Incorporation date: 6 Jan 2026 Status: Active Directors: Lloyd Birrell (CEO, Lions Bay Resources) Deon Robbertze Why it’s interesting: Timing is notable — incorporation comes immediately after Lions Bay’s bid for the Vantage Goldfields / Lily / Barbrook assets crystallised. Director overlap with Lions Bay Resources strongly suggests this is not a random shelf company. Looks like a logical local operating / acquisition SPV for South African assets: potential asset holding vehicle, interface with DMRE / Section 11 consents, contracting with BRPs / creditors, ring-fencing SA operational and rehabilitation obligations from offshore listed entities. Context? Sits neatly alongside: Lions Bay Capital (TSXV-listed sponsor), Lions Bay Resources (operating platform), Metals One (strategic backer), and the ongoing Vantage business rescue / asset process. From what I've seen before creation of a clean SA entity at this stage is standard practice in mining restructurings where assets are expected to transition out of business rescue..... Bottom line: Nothing “announced” yet — but the existence, timing and directors make Lions Bay Mining a useful entity to watch for

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Industry expert calls for urgent resuscitation of SA’s gold sector Nokukhanya Mntambo Nokukhanya Mntambo 6 February 2026 | 7:52 While South Africa is still among the big players in the global gold market, the country has been surpassed by a number of countries, including China and Ghana. Gold mine collapse Gold Lily Mine Industry expert calls for urgent resuscitation of SA’s gold sector Lily Mine in Barberton, near Mpumalanga. Picture: Sphamandla Dlamini/EWN Senior gold industry executive and CEO of Lions Bay Resources, Lloyd Birrell, believes urgent interventions are needed to pull back the decline in the country’s gold mining industry. While South Africa is still among the big players in the global gold market, the country has been surpassed by a number of countries, including China and Ghana. Mining in South Africa faces increasing challenges, including declining ore grades and increasing operational costs affecting the bottom line. Calls for lower electricity costs are among the demands from miners squeezed by prices. According to Mining Weekly, local gold production has been shrinking at an average rate of 5.8% a year since 1994, falling from 580 tonnes to less than 90 tonnes in 2024. Last year, China’s production of the precious metal was almost four times South Africa’s production. Although gold prices have come down from the January 29 highs, the precious metal surpassed the $5, 500 mark per ounce this year. Birrell explained: “It’s extraordinary that at a gold price like this, South Africa’s gold mining has declined to the extent that it has.” Birrell’s Lions Bay Resources is among the interested bidders for the derelict Lily Gold mine near Barberton after its 2016 closure. But the process to get the mine out of business rescue remains stalled by a series of litigations. Lily Mine is the site of the 2016 tragedy where three mineworkers were trapped underground in a container following a fall of ground accident. Their remains were never retrieved. Birrell was among those at the mine on Thursday, where the families of Pretty Nkambule, Yvonne Mnisi and Solomon Nyirenda marked the 10th anniversary of the tragedy. He believes his firm has the capital and expertise to revive the now-flooded Lily Mine, which is a complex and technical process. “Now, our plan is, because we know what the disadvantages or the difficulties with Lily are, is that we would open Brookbrook, and we could use all the infrastructure and the deposition available. We would be operating underground in Barbrook within nine months. We have the capacity and the operation, operational capacity, and the plant is there. We can do it in nine months. So, we can catch up some time, and then we can, then we can spend the next three years dewatering and reestablishing lily, said Birrell.”

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Fell CUR (Current Price) is the reference price the market displays as “the price” at any given moment, but it only updates when a trade is allowed to go through the lit order book in a way that qualifies as price-forming. Large trades done off-book, negotiated crosses, or internalised trades can change ownership without moving CUR at all. So CUR can be held still for long periods even while substantial volume trades elsewhere, making it look quiet or weak to retail — when in reality liquidity is being absorbed or redistributed behind the scenes.

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: You could argue that across North America, governments are starting to treat old mine waste and tailings less as environmental problems and more as useful resources that can be cleaned up and reused. This does fit neatly with national-security goals around securing domestic supplies of critical minerals like uranium and vanadium. Canada has already shown that reprocessing old waste can be permitted faster and supported by public policy, and the US is now applying similar thinking through frameworks linked to NISA of which we obviously have agreements with on the Uranium side.  Companies like Fulcrum are literally playing into that Narrative. And in turn, the potential of short term revenue etc etc etc

data.author: andymlloyd
data.content: Another cracker of an RNS, if you read between the lines. MET1 have just upped their stake in Fulcrum Metals (FMET) to 6.33% by exercising warrants at 5p — not selling, not trimming… doubling down. This tells us: Initial £175k investment is now up over 100% (unrealised) FMET share price has more than doubled in ~6 months MET1 are confident enough to: Increase exposure now Take new warrants at 10p valid for 18 months (i.e. expecting much higher prices ahead) This isn’t retail punt behaviour, this is strategic capital allocation. And Fulcrum isn’t just another junior either: Cyanide-free metal recovery (ESG box ticked ) Reprocessing mine tailings (low capex, high margin potential) Canada-based projects (Teck-Hughes & Sylvanite) Using proven tech from Extrakt Process Solutions Read the MD quote carefully, he’s basically telling you: Progress is real, price action is justified, and the next stage is coming. Meanwhile MET1 holders get: NAV uplift Exposure to a second critical metals story Optionality via 10p warrants Proof management can pick winners and monetise early For a company that’s still massively undervalued on its own projects, this is exactly the sort of RNS that often gets ignored, right before the market wakes up. DYOR (Be Nice to Each Other, Cue the Muppets)

data.author: i-man
data.content: Metals One acquired approximately 19–20% of Lions Bay Capital Inc., a Canadian-listed mining finance company. This investment was made through: A C$750,000 subscription for 7.5 million Lions Bay shares. A later strategic investment of up to US$1.8 million in Lions Bay Resources (a South African private company jointly owned by Lions Bay Capital and Salamander Mining). What the Lions Bay Project Actually Is Lions Bay’s priority project is reviving a gold processing plant in South Africa, which previously shut down in 2021 after only 18 months of operation. The plant is expected to be back in production by Q4 2026, offering near‑term cash flow potential. Lions Bay holds an option to acquire the plant’s cogeneration facility for US$1.4 million, which originally cost around US$20 million to build. Metals One sees the project as: A low‑cost entry into gold production through a partner rather than direct mine development. A way to balance its portfolio, which includes earlier‑stage uranium and critical metals exploration. An opportunity to gain exposure to South African gold assets managed by experienced operators, including former executives from major gold companies. Metals One is not developing a gold mine itself in Africa. Instead, it has taken a significant minority stake in Lions Bay Capital and Lions Bay Resources to support and benefit from the restart of a South African gold processing plant, expected to generate cash flow in the near term.

data.author: LaGomera
data.content: Wise and succinct words from "allforprofit", but before anyone posts a response, there are one or two exceptions. However, cast your minds back to the extensive hype that propelled the price; the changing prospects; the discounted fundraising.  How frequently do investors in high risk minnows see this? Dream on, ye delusionists, who ooze confidence that multi-£ market share prices will ensue.  None comment upon the wider mining market or the merger talks involving RTZ. "allforprofits'" wise words should be heeded, and, might I add, whilst there is enjoyment to be had from investing in more speculative shares, only invest what you are prepared to write-off, the nano-second after you have parted with your money. Expert VC's expect to not make money from most of their investments, but to do so well from one or two of the "good-uns" that they can boast returns on their portfolio. Enjoy the weekend and best wishes to all.

data.author: Laura2022
data.content: Recently SAV got over €100mln from Portugal Daniel Maling, Managing Director of Metals One, commented: "Access to raw materials is essential for the EU's economy and the functioning of the internal market. The Black Schist Project is a multi-metal extraction project potentially contributing to the Union's security of supply for several Strategic Raw Materials. Strategic Project designation would provide several key advantages that could aid in the project's development and long-term success, including but not limited to enhanced access to project financing, including eligibility for funding from EU programmes, and streamlined permitting processes. Given the key role of many critical raw materials in realising the green and digital transitions, and considering their use for defence and aerospace applications, demand is likely to increase exponentially in the coming decades. Further, risk of supply disruptions is increasing against the background of rising geopolitical tensions and resource competition. We believe our Black Schist Project can contribute a stable and secure resource of strategic and critical metals to the EU market."

data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (AIM:MET1) completed significant fundraisings in 2025, raising over £15 million to diversify into high-potential gold and uranium projects alongside their existing battery metal assets. While the company is positioned for growth with a strengthened portfolio, analysts suggest recovery to previous highs is heavily dependent on resource validation, project development, and sustained high commodity prices. Key Findings for 2025-2026: Strategic Transformation: In April 2025, the company secured funding to expand its portfolio, focusing on copper and uranium to complement its existing nickel projects. Market Conditions: The firm aimed to leverage record-high gold and commodity prices to drive value. Performance: Despite potential, the stock experienced volatility, falling 80% from a 52-week high in mid-2025, but was actively looking to recover through new acquisitions in Finland, Norway, and the USA. Outlook: As of late 2025, the firm was focused on drilling and developing these new, high-impact projects to drive long-term value. The company's success relies on whether its newly acquired projects can deliver on their projected value to boost share price.

data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (MET1) has shown capacity to attract institutional support, particularly during capital raises for its battery metal projects in Europe, though it remains a high-risk, high-reward, small-cap, pre-revenue entity. Based on 2025 and early 2026 data, here is an analysis of Metals One's appeal to institutional investors: Factors Attracting Institutional Investors: Strategic Assets in Favorable Locations: Metals One operates in Finland (Black Schist Project) and Norway (Råna Project), jurisdictions with strong local demand for EV battery materials (nickel, copper, cobalt) and favorable mining regulations. Support During Fundraising: The company has successfully secured funding with "institutional and retail backing," such as the £3.1 million equity raise in April 2025 to fund project development. Industry Focus: The company’s focus on critical metals for the energy transition aligns with thematic investing trends, making it attractive to specialized natural resource funds. Partnerships and Growth: The company has initiated strategic investments and acquisitions (e.g., in Fidelity Minerals Corp and CleanTech Lithium), which can attract institutional attention.

data.title: Further Investment in Evolution Energy Minerals
data.full_content:
Today 07:00
RNS Number : 4997S
Metals One PLC
11 February 2026
11 February 2026
Metals One Plc
("Metals One" or the "Company")
Further Investment in Evolution Energy Minerals
Metals One (AIM: MET1, OTCQB: MTOPF), a critical and precious metals project developer and investor, announces it intends to participate in a fundraising by Evolution Energy Minerals Ltd (ASX: EV1) ("Evolution") (Metals One: 16.9%) by way of participation in a pro rata renounceable entitlement offer announced by Evolution this morning.
Evolution has confirmed eligible shareholders are able to subscribe for one new fully paid ordinary share in Evolution for every two existing fully paid ordinary shares held, at an issue price of A$0.015 per new share, with Evolution seeking to raise up to approximately A$4 million before costs. The issue price represents a premium to the Company's original investment price per share of A$0.011.
Metals One has agreed to invest up to A$1 million as part of the transaction (the "Metals One Subscription") although its final allocation will be determined by the take-up from other shareholders and therefore a further announcement will be made once this is finalised.
The proceeds from the fundraising will be applied to exploration of the Chikundo Copper Project, resource development activities at the Chilalo Graphite Project, costs associated with the fundraising, short term loan repayments and for general working capital.
Craig Moulton, the Company's Chairman, remains an executive director of Evolution and therefore the Metals One Subscription is considered a Related Party Transaction under the AIM Rules. The independent directors of Metals One, being Daniel Maling, Alex King and Fungai Ndoro, having consulted with the Company's Nominated Advisor, consider the terms of the Metals One Subscription to be fair and reasonable and in the best interests of the Company and its shareholders.
For the financial year ended 30 June 2025, Evolution reported a loss before tax of A$5,105,930 on nil revenue and, as at that date, had Net Assets of A$5,092,624.
Daniel Maling, Managing Director of Metals One, commented:
"We remain a highly supportive investor in Evolution and are pleased to participate in this fundraising. The additional capital has been raised to support the Company's advancement of the Chikundo Copper Project and Evolution's broader exploration and development activities."
The full text of Evolution's announcement is reproduced below and available on their website here:
https://evolutionenergyminerals.com.au/asx-announcements/
Renounceable Entitlement Offer to raise up to $4 million
·
1 for 2 renounceable rights issue to raise up to $4,032,830
·
Attractively priced at $0.015 per share
·
Discount of 25% to the 30-day VWAP of 2 cents
·
With every two New Shares subscribed, shareholders receive one free attaching New Option
·
New Options will have an exercise price of $0.02 and expiry on 17 September 2028, in the same class as EV1O and will be quoted on the ASX
·
Shareholders can trade their rights and apply for additional shares and options under the Top Up Offer
·
The Directors intend to participate by taking up their Entitlement
·
Major shareholder Metals One Plc to invest $1 million and increase its holding
Evolution Energy Minerals Limited ("EV1" or the "Company") is pleased to announce that it is undertaking a pro-rata renounceable entitlement offer to eligible shareholders to subscribe for one new fully paid ordinary share in the Company ("New Share") for every two existing fully paid ordinary shares ("Shares") held as at 5:00pm (AWST) on the record date, being Monday, 16 February 2026 ("Record Date") ("Entitlement"), at an issue price of A$0.015 per New Share ("Offer Price") to raise up to approximately $4 million ("Entitlement Offer") before costs.
Shareholders will receive one free attaching option for every two New Shares acquired under the Entitlement Offer, with an exercise price of $0.02 and expiring on 17 September 2028, in the same class as the existing EV1O options ("New Options"). The New Options will be quoted under the ASX code EV1O.
The Entitlement Offer includes a top up offer ("Top Up Offer") under which eligible shareholders who have taken up their full entitlement under the Entitlement Offer can apply for additional New Shares and attaching New Options in excess of their Entitlement, subject to restrictions under Chapter 6 of the Corporations Act. Applications under the Top Up Offer will only be considered to the extent that there is a shortfall under the Entitlement Offer.
Assuming no options are exercised before the Record Date, up to approximately 268,855,338 New Shares and approximately 134,427,669 New Options will be issued under the Entitlement Offer. As the Entitlement Offer is renounceable, the rights will be tradeable on the ASX from the commencement of the rights trading on Friday, 13 February 2026, and are also otherwise transferable in accordance with the timetable for the En

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: J Batch My only commentary was around Look through NAV and how those investments are seen. The Fulcrum one hasn't been crystallised, and saying we've made paper money helps but doesn't particularly add anything meaningful to look through NAV. Cleantech lithium yes they've essentially made 100% profit and left in 6% ish free carry, which is good business. But when you have unknowns / risk profiles around LBR / LBI and arguably EV1 then from a look through perspective its pretty much cash position ( with some cash burn) and yes x % attributable to these investments. So in my rough calls you're probably currently looking at around 1.8 look through NAV base and maybe some premium attributed to project (direct) optionality. But the market is currently saying right now, this is how we are pricing it, thus the churn around 1.85 - 2.05 mark and that's literally what it is. Until something like LBR court process comes to a conclusion or there is a catalyst from Uranium or possibly some timeline assigned to exploration at Swales Gold then this is going to bobble about. I'm not saying that's necessarily a negative thing. I've done extensive research on both Novacore Claim mapping with historical academic study overlays, so have a good idea what they're potentially sitting on, especially when you input some of Myriad Uranium Magnetic and Radiometric Counts into those overlays, that for me is the key. And I can pretty much work out where they with drill first which is probably NC 311 34.3833°N 107.8730°W.). I've done same with Swales geologically / archive overlays so quite comfortable with that, but truly believe they will push the Uranium side first. Vanadium Kings again, strong strong area, and NISA narrative will play out soon enough. I'm not necessarily being negative, just literally assigning some logic to where the price is today. To a degree with the LBR narrative as it's played out you could even argue the placing was done on a slight premium. Unfortunately with LBI they've created a  balance-sheet choreography risk which will mute any peripheral RNS' right now. I've listened to Lloyd Birrel (LBR) talk recently and he very much sounds like he is on it, but there are so many factors that need to go right in that process for it to succeed even if the court case goes well (it's been going since 2016 and they've tried it before in 2020) so you still have Section 11 to tackle beyond any Business Rescue Process. So because of all that, only something very powerful from the Uranium side in my opinion will make a difference.

data.content: I tend to agree LTI. It needs a meaningful Uranium update, ideally for Novacore Red Basin project to give this any meaningful momentum. Even if you set look through NAV at 1.8 - 1.9 and that gives you literally a factor of zero success across any project, it's probably where it should be right now, especially with the complexity on LBR. data.author: Chilli300
data.content: You could even go a bit more technical and discuss exchange feed and sequencing Cur reflects the last trade processed by the exchange feed, not necessarily the last line you see in the scrolling trade list. Trades can be reported out of execution sequence, especially off-book or across venues, which is why you can sometimes see lower prints listed after the headline price.”
data.thread_title: RE: Not sure I get this.

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Because it was CUR displaying The “Cur” being stuck at 2.0495 was just a snapshot artefact. “Cur” price basically reflects the last reported trade, not necessarily where the market is currently balanced. In small-cap names especially, a single on-book aggressive print — where a buyer lifts the offer or a seller hits the bid and consumes visible liquidity — can set the headline price even if there’s no follow-through. By contrast, off-book or negotiated trades can add volume without expressing real directional intent. So when you see the stock showing +7% but trading repeatedly back near 1.98p, that usually means the earlier aggressive probe defined the “Cur”, while the real equilibrium has already rotated lower.

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: 11 February 2026 Fulcrum Metals plc ("Fulcrum" or the "Company" or the "Group") Fulcrum initiates Pilot Plant Scoping Study for its Tailings Projects Fulcrum Metals plc (AIM: FMET), a company pioneering the use of innovative cyanide-free technologies to recover precious and critical metals from historic mine waste, is pleased to announce the initiation of a Pilot Plant Scoping Study (the "Study") with Test Design Implement Solutions LLC ("TDI") for upscaling work at its Teck Hughes and Sylvanite tailings projects in Kirkland Lake, Ontario. TDI will be supported by Extrakt Process Solutions LLC ("Extrakt") and Bechtel Energy Technologies & Solutions, Inc. ("Bechtel"). Fulcrum has commissioned TDI to undertake the Study to identify the best way to advance from successful laboratory scale tests to a pilot-scale operation. This important decision was taken after assessment of the Phase 3 optimisation metallurgical results announced by the Company on 9 February 2026, which demonstrated materially improved gold recoveries, polymetallic potential and operational efficiencies using the Extrakt process. Strategic Importance for Fulcrum Successful pilot-scale demonstration is an important technical and commercial de-risking step for all tailings reprocessing projects. This study will provide Fulcrum with a framework to implement a standalone pilot plant to upscale from laboratory to pilot tests for all Fulcrum projects, and for potential asset partners. Ryan Mee, Chief Executive Officer of Fulcrum Metals plc, commented: "Pilot plant success is one of the most important de-risking moments in any project lifecycle. "Following the excellent Phase 3 optimisation results announced earlier this week, we now intend to determine a clear and disciplined approach to pilot-scale testing. This standalone pilot plant will serve as a module for flexible upscaling of our existing and potential future projects. "We look forward to working closely with TDI, Extrakt and Bechtel on this important next stage of development." Pilot Plant Scoping Study - Purpose and Scope The Study will evaluate the technical, logistical and execution requirements for a pilot-scale leaching plant integrated with Extrakt's Reagent Management System ("RMS"). The work is intended to support informed decision-making ahead of any pilot plant implementation. Key elements for assessment will include: ·    Pilot plant configuration and scale options ·    Alternative pilot locations and associated logistics ·    Vendor, laboratory and contracting strategies ·    Governance frameworks and Qualified Person (QP) involvement ·    Execution strategy and sequencing The Study will also identify key risks and recommend high-level mitigation measures, to outline a clear path forward for detailed engineering and pilot execution. The Study is expected to be completed in approximately 10 weeks. Key Deliverables The Study will deliver a Pilot Pla

data.author: Castlepaul13
data.content: 11 February 2026 Metals One Plc ("Metals One" or the "Company") Further Investment in Evolution Energy Minerals Metals One (AIM: MET1, OTCQB: MTOPF), a critical and precious metals project developer and investor, announces it intends to participate in a fundraising by Evolution Energy Minerals Ltd (ASX: EV1) ("Evolution") (Metals One: 16.9%) by way of participation in a pro rata renounceable entitlement offer announced by Evolution this morning. Evolution has confirmed eligible shareholders are able to subscribe for one new fully paid ordinary share in Evolution for every two existing fully paid ordinary shares held, at an issue price of A$0.015 per new share, with Evolution seeking to raise up to approximately A$4 million before costs. The issue price represents a premium to the Company's original investment price per share of A$0.011. Metals One has agreed to invest up to A$1 million as part of the transaction (the "Metals One Subscription") although its final allocation will be determined by the take-up from other shareholders and therefore a further announcement will be made once this is finalised. The proceeds from the fundraising will be applied to exploration of the Chikundo Copper Project, resource development activities at the Chilalo Graphite Project, costs associated with the fundraising, short term loan repayments and for general working capital. Craig Moulton, the Company's Chairman, remains an executive director of Evolution and therefore the Metals One Subscription is considered a Related Party Transaction under the AIM Rules. The independent directors of Metals One, being Daniel Maling, Alex King and Fungai Ndoro, having consulted with the Company's Nominated Advisor, consider the terms of the Metals One Subscription to be fair and reasonable and in the best interests of the Company and its shareholders. For the financial year ended 30 June 2025, Evolution reported a loss before tax of A$5,105,930 on nil revenue and, as at that date, had Net Assets of A$5,092,624. Daniel Maling, Managing Director of Metals One, commented: "We remain a highly supportive investor in Evolution and are pleased to participate in this fundraising. The additional capital has been raised to support the Company's advancement of the Chikundo Copper Project and Evolution's broader exploration and development activities."

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: For anyone following MET1’s US uranium exposure, it’s worth independently researching why BHP has pulled the Utah Geological Survey into its Xplor program, and what that signals about how major miners now approach early-stage discovery. This isn’t about individual projects being “picked”; it’s about district-scale mineral systems being re-evaluated — and companies already embedded in those systems arguably  stand to benefit first. BHP’s inclusion of the Utah Geological Survey reflects a clear shift toward regional mineral-systems thinking, authoritative public-domain data, and modern reinterpretation of historic geology before capital-intensive drilling. UGS’ role focuses on state-wide and regional geological frameworks — integrating historic datasets, modern geophysics, and targeted fieldwork — rather than endorsing individual projects, and that work informs understanding of sediment-hosted uranium-vanadium systems across Utah and the wider Colorado Plateau margin. In that context, MET1’s Vanadium King Project in Utah sits within the Uravan Mineral Belt and is hosted in the same sandstone unit that underpins multiple historic uranium-vanadium deposits across the region. While the host horizon itself is continuous, higher-grade mineralisation occurs in localised zones rather than as a uniform sheet, which is normal for this deposit style. Historic drilling and workings at Vanadium King intersected uranium and vanadium at the correct geological level, confirming the presence of a proven regional system rather than an isolated occurrence. Academic and public-domain studies across the Uravan Belt show this type of mineralisation to be predictable when viewed at system level, even though grades vary from place to place. As state-level geological frameworks are modernised and published, projects already positioned within validated systems — such as MET1’s Uravan Belt assets — can possibly gain strategic relevance without forcing near-term drilling or promotional noise? Thoughts?

data.content: In 2025, Metals One PLC (AIM: MET1) announced the acquisition of the Hammaslahti and Outokumpu copper projects in Finland from 80 Mile PLC. Located in Eastern Finland, these projects include high-potential exploration targets associated with former, high-grade copper mines. data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (AIM: MET1) is primarily an exploration and development company, with its investment, Evolution Energy Minerals (16.9% stake), targeting first ore production at the Chilalo Graphite Project by October 2027. The company focuses on developing projects in Finland and the U.S., rather than immediate direct production. Key Production and Development Timelines: Chilalo Graphite Project (via Evolution): Accelerated development schedule aims for first ore mining by October 2027. Hammaslahti/Outokumpu Projects (Finland): Following 2025 acquisitions and drilling, the company is focused on resource expansion. U.S. Uranium/Vanadium Projects: Acquisitions in Colorado/Utah were completed in 2025, targeting exploration rather than immediate production. Metals One operates as an investor/developer, aiming to build a portfolio of assets to supply critical minerals to Western markets.

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: In 2025, Metals One PLC (AIM: MET1) announced the acquisition of the Hammaslahti and Outokumpu copper projects in Finland from 80 Mile PLC. Located in Eastern Finland, these projects include high-potential exploration targets associated with former, high-grade copper mines. However, by July 2025, Metals One decided not to proceed with this acquisition, shifting focus to US-based critical minerals.
data.thread_title: RE: Step By Step but moving forward nicely

data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (AIM: MET1) is primarily an exploration and development company, with its investment, Evolution Energy Minerals (16.9% stake), targeting first ore production at the Chilalo Graphite Project by October 2027. The company focuses on developing projects in Finland and the U.S., rather than immediate direct production. Key Production and Development Timelines: Chilalo Graphite Project (via Evolution): Accelerated development schedule aims for first ore mining by October 2027. Hammaslahti/Outokumpu Projects (Finland): Following 2025 acquisitions and drilling, the company is focused on resource expansion. U.S. Uranium/Vanadium Projects: Acquisitions in Colorado/Utah were completed in 2025, targeting exploration rather than immediate production. Metals One operates as an investor/developer, aiming to build a portfolio of assets to supply critical minerals to Western markets.

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Lions Bay Mining (Pty) Ltd – new SA entity worth noting? Quick heads-up for those tracking the Lions Bay / MET1 / Vantage situation. A new South African company, Lions Bay Mining (Pty) Ltd (Enterprise No. K2026004873), was incorporated on 6 January 2026 and is currently active. Key points: Jurisdiction: South Africa Incorporation date: 6 Jan 2026 Status: Active Directors: Lloyd Birrell (CEO, Lions Bay Resources) Deon Robbertze Why it’s interesting: Timing is notable — incorporation comes immediately after Lions Bay’s bid for the Vantage Goldfields / Lily / Barbrook assets crystallised. Director overlap with Lions Bay Resources strongly suggests this is not a random shelf company. Looks like a logical local operating / acquisition SPV for South African assets: potential asset holding vehicle, interface with DMRE / Section 11 consents, contracting with BRPs / creditors, ring-fencing SA operational and rehabilitation obligations from offshore listed entities. Context? Sits neatly alongside: Lions Bay Capital (TSXV-listed sponsor), Lions Bay Resources (operating platform), Metals One (strategic backer), and the ongoing Vantage business rescue / asset process. From what I've seen before creation of a clean SA entity at this stage is standard practice in mining restructurings where assets are expected to transition out of business rescue..... Bottom line: Nothing “announced” yet — but the existence, timing and directors make Lions Bay Mining a useful entity to watch for

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Industry expert calls for urgent resuscitation of SA’s gold sector Nokukhanya Mntambo Nokukhanya Mntambo 6 February 2026 | 7:52 While South Africa is still among the big players in the global gold market, the country has been surpassed by a number of countries, including China and Ghana. Gold mine collapse Gold Lily Mine Industry expert calls for urgent resuscitation of SA’s gold sector Lily Mine in Barberton, near Mpumalanga. Picture: Sphamandla Dlamini/EWN Senior gold industry executive and CEO of Lions Bay Resources, Lloyd Birrell, believes urgent interventions are needed to pull back the decline in the country’s gold mining industry. While South Africa is still among the big players in the global gold market, the country has been surpassed by a number of countries, including China and Ghana. Mining in South Africa faces increasing challenges, including declining ore grades and increasing operational costs affecting the bottom line. Calls for lower electricity costs are among the demands from miners squeezed by prices. According to Mining Weekly, local gold production has been shrinking at an average rate of 5.8% a year since 1994, falling from 580 tonnes to less than 90 tonnes in 2024. Last year, China’s production of the precious metal was almost four times South Africa’s production. Although gold prices have come down from the January 29 highs, the precious metal surpassed the $5, 500 mark per ounce this year. Birrell explained: “It’s extraordinary that at a gold price like this, South Africa’s gold mining has declined to the extent that it has.” Birrell’s Lions Bay Resources is among the interested bidders for the derelict Lily Gold mine near Barberton after its 2016 closure. But the process to get the mine out of business rescue remains stalled by a series of litigations. Lily Mine is the site of the 2016 tragedy where three mineworkers were trapped underground in a container following a fall of ground accident. Their remains were never retrieved. Birrell was among those at the mine on Thursday, where the families of Pretty Nkambule, Yvonne Mnisi and Solomon Nyirenda marked the 10th anniversary of the tragedy. He believes his firm has the capital and expertise to revive the now-flooded Lily Mine, which is a complex and technical process. “Now, our plan is, because we know what the disadvantages or the difficulties with Lily are, is that we would open Brookbrook, and we could use all the infrastructure and the deposition available. We would be operating underground in Barbrook within nine months. We have the capacity and the operation, operational capacity, and the plant is there. We can do it in nine months. So, we can catch up some time, and then we can, then we can spend the next three years dewatering and reestablishing lily, said Birrell.”

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Fascinating timing just a few days before Indaba 2026 nothing like a bit of ESG angle to speed up DMRE engagement and BRP decisions Mining experts flag looming environmental challenges at Lily Mine Nokukhanya Mntambo 6 February 2026 | 4:31 The mine shut its doors in 2016 after a deadly structural collapse. Lily Mine Mining experts flag looming environmental challenges at Lily Mine A gate leading at the Lily Mine near Baberton, in Mpumalanga, leading to the scene where victims Pretty Nkambule, Solomon Nyirenda and Yvonne Mnisi were trapped underground a decade ago. Picture: Sphamandla Dlamini/EWN Some mining experts have raised concerns about the looming environmental challenges of the now-derelict Lily gold mine near Barberton, in Mpumalanga. The mine shut its doors in 2016 after a deadly structural collapse. Pretty Nkambule, Solomon Nyirenda and Yvonne Mnisi were trapped underground a decade ago following the collapse of Lily Mine. Their bodies were never recovered. ALSO READ: Potential Lily Mine investors: Red tape hampers Efforts to resume operations The senior gold industry executive and CEO of Lions Bay Resources, Lloyd Birrell, said flooding in the Lily gold mine could have a spillover effect on the agriculture downstream if the water makes its way into the irrigation canal. “The difficulty is that when water collects in a mine, a chemical process then takes place. Eventually, the water changes its pH. It can become extremely low, which means it's acidic, which means it dissolves other metals, like arsenic or manganese or, for example, nickel. These are not good things to have dissolved in the water.” He said it also has a damaging effect for the local community. “Now the community doesn't have safe drinking water anymore, and what we need to ascertain is whether or not that is caused by the huge volume of water sitting underground, which is mutating, either becoming excessively alkaline and with a low pH, which is not a good, not a good combination. So, there is a significant environmental component to reopening this mine.”

data.author: Chilli300
data.content: Fell CUR (Current Price) is the reference price the market displays as “the price” at any given moment, but it only updates when a trade is allowed to go through the lit order book in a way that qualifies as price-forming. Large trades done off-book, negotiated crosses, or internalised trades can change ownership without moving CUR at all. So CUR can be held still for long periods even while substantial volume trades elsewhere, making it look quiet or weak to retail — when in reality liquidity is being absorbed or redistributed behind the scenes.

The main difference today is that we seem to be trading in a slightly higher band (for now) 1.98 - 2.1 rather than 1.91 - 1.98 in the main. data.author: Chilli300
data.content: You could argue that across North America, governments are starting to treat old mine waste and tailings less as environmental problems and more as useful resources that can be cleaned up and reused. This does fit neatly with national-security goals around securing domestic supplies of critical minerals like uranium and vanadium. Canada has already shown that reprocessing old waste can be permitted faster and supported by public policy, and the US is now applying similar thinking through frameworks linked to NISA of which we obviously have agreements with on the Uranium side.  Companies like Fulcrum are literally playing into that Narrative. And in turn, the potential of short term revenue etc etc etc

data.author: andymlloyd
data.content: Another cracker of an RNS, if you read between the lines. MET1 have just upped their stake in Fulcrum Metals (FMET) to 6.33% by exercising warrants at 5p — not selling, not trimming… doubling down. This tells us: Initial £175k investment is now up over 100% (unrealised) FMET share price has more than doubled in ~6 months MET1 are confident enough to: Increase exposure now Take new warrants at 10p valid for 18 months (i.e. expecting much higher prices ahead) This isn’t retail punt behaviour, this is strategic capital allocation. And Fulcrum isn’t just another junior either: Cyanide-free metal recovery (ESG box ticked ) Reprocessing mine tailings (low capex, high margin potential) Canada-based projects (Teck-Hughes & Sylvanite) Using proven tech from Extrakt Process Solutions Read the MD quote carefully, he’s basically telling you: Progress is real, price action is justified, and the next stage is coming. Meanwhile MET1 holders get: NAV uplift Exposure to a second critical metals story Optionality via 10p warrants Proof management can pick winners and monetise early For a company that’s still massively undervalued on its own projects, this is exactly the sort of RNS that often gets ignored, right before the market wakes up. DYOR (Be Nice to Each Other, Cue the Muppets)

data.content: Before anyone points it out, I know we are only talking about a small unrealised gain so far in our investment in Fulcrum of around £175,000. However, Met1 has exercised nearly 3m more warrants at a 25% discount, now owning just over 6% of Fulcrum’s share capital. That’s good business to me. I want to see steady and incremental positives steps in restoring our faith in Met1 and they are now going in the right direction. This will bring back investors IMO Fell

data.author: i-man
data.content: Metals One acquired approximately 19–20% of Lions Bay Capital Inc., a Canadian-listed mining finance company. This investment was made through: A C$750,000 subscription for 7.5 million Lions Bay shares. A later strategic investment of up to US$1.8 million in Lions Bay Resources (a South African private company jointly owned by Lions Bay Capital and Salamander Mining). What the Lions Bay Project Actually Is Lions Bay’s priority project is reviving a gold processing plant in South Africa, which previously shut down in 2021 after only 18 months of operation. The plant is expected to be back in production by Q4 2026, offering near‑term cash flow potential. Lions Bay holds an option to acquire the plant’s cogeneration facility for US$1.4 million, which originally cost around US$20 million to build. Metals One sees the project as: A low‑cost entry into gold production through a partner rather than direct mine development. A way to balance its portfolio, which includes earlier‑stage uranium and critical metals exploration. An opportunity to gain exposure to South African gold assets managed by experienced operators, including former executives from major gold companies. Metals One is not developing a gold mine itself in Africa. Instead, it has taken a significant minority stake in Lions Bay Capital and Lions Bay Resources to support and benefit from the restart of a South African gold processing plant, expected to generate cash flow in the near term.

data.author: LaGomera
data.content: Wise and succinct words from "allforprofit", but before anyone posts a response, there are one or two exceptions. However, cast your minds back to the extensive hype that propelled the price; the changing prospects; the discounted fundraising.  How frequently do investors in high risk minnows see this? Dream on, ye delusionists, who ooze confidence that multi-£ market share prices will ensue.  None comment upon the wider mining market or the merger talks involving RTZ. "allforprofits'" wise words should be heeded, and, might I add, whilst there is enjoyment to be had from investing in more speculative shares, only invest what you are prepared to write-off, the nano-second after you have parted with your money. Expert VC's expect to not make money from most of their investments, but to do so well from one or two of the "good-uns" that they can boast returns on their portfolio. Enjoy the weekend and best wishes to all.

data.author: Laura2022
data.content: Recently SAV got over €100mln from Portugal Daniel Maling, Managing Director of Metals One, commented: "Access to raw materials is essential for the EU's economy and the functioning of the internal market. The Black Schist Project is a multi-metal extraction project potentially contributing to the Union's security of supply for several Strategic Raw Materials. Strategic Project designation would provide several key advantages that could aid in the project's development and long-term success, including but not limited to enhanced access to project financing, including eligibility for funding from EU programmes, and streamlined permitting processes. Given the key role of many critical raw materials in realising the green and digital transitions, and considering their use for defence and aerospace applications, demand is likely to increase exponentially in the coming decades. Further, risk of supply disruptions is increasing against the background of rising geopolitical tensions and resource competition. We believe our Black Schist Project can contribute a stable and secure resource of strategic and critical metals to the EU market."

data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (AIM:MET1) completed significant fundraisings in 2025, raising over £15 million to diversify into high-potential gold and uranium projects alongside their existing battery metal assets. While the company is positioned for growth with a strengthened portfolio, analysts suggest recovery to previous highs is heavily dependent on resource validation, project development, and sustained high commodity prices. Key Findings for 2025-2026: Strategic Transformation: In April 2025, the company secured funding to expand its portfolio, focusing on copper and uranium to complement its existing nickel projects. Market Conditions: The firm aimed to leverage record-high gold and commodity prices to drive value. Performance: Despite potential, the stock experienced volatility, falling 80% from a 52-week high in mid-2025, but was actively looking to recover through new acquisitions in Finland, Norway, and the USA. Outlook: As of late 2025, the firm was focused on drilling and developing these new, high-impact projects to drive long-term value. The company's success relies on whether its newly acquired projects can deliver on their projected value to boost share price.
data.thread_title: Will metals one plc recover to its 2025 highest price

data.author: Anxiety
data.content: Metals One PLC (MET1) has shown capacity to attract institutional support, particularly during capital raises for its battery metal projects in Europe, though it remains a high-risk, high-reward, small-cap, pre-revenue entity. Based on 2025 and early 2026 data, here is an analysis of Metals One's appeal to institutional investors: Factors Attracting Institutional Investors: Strategic Assets in Favorable Locations: Metals One operates in Finland (Black Schist Project) and Norway (Råna Project), jurisdictions with strong local demand for EV battery materials (nickel, copper, cobalt) and favorable mining regulations. Support During Fundraising: The company has successfully secured funding with "institutional and retail backing," such as the £3.1 million equity raise in April 2025 to fund project development. Industry Focus: The company’s focus on critical metals for the energy transition aligns with thematic investing trends, making it attractive to specialized natural resource funds. Partnerships and Growth: The company has initiated strategic investments and acquisitions (e.g., in Fidelity Minerals Corp and CleanTech Lithium), which can attract institutional attention.

data.author: PaulMoore
data.content: The United States is planning to inject $1.6 billion into Oklahoma-based miner USA Rare Earth and will receive a 10% stake ​in the company, the Financial Times reported on Saturday, citing people ‌familiar with the matter.

company_30s.what_they_do: Metals One plc is an investment vehicle that buys stakes in mining and metals companies, mainly in the UK and Australia. It focuses on small to mid‑size projects that are still in the early development stage.
company_30s.why_they_matter: The mining sector is a key part of the global supply chain for metals used in technology, construction and clean‑energy products. Small miners can deliver big upside when commodity prices rise or when a project reaches a milestone.
company_30s.current_state: Metals One is still raising capital and allocating it to new projects such as Evolution Energy Minerals and Lions Bay. The company has been quiet on the market, trading near its lowest point in recent history.

rns_narrative: Metals One has just completed a series of capital‑raising moves, securing fresh funding to back a handful of promising mining ventures.

The latest updates show the company investing in Evolution Energy Minerals and Lions Bay, both of which are working on early‑stage projects that could become profitable if commodity prices move higher.
These moves are classic survival tactics for a small miner – they keep the business afloat while waiting for a catalyst that will unlock value.

crowd_tape.dominant_theme: Total abandonment – no one is talking about the stock.
crowd_tape.bull_narrative: No bullish chatter – the market has moved on.
crowd_tape.bear_narrative: Bears are still pointing out the lack of progress and the risk of a small‑cap miner stalling.
crowd_tape.sentiment_shift: The market went from panic to apathy; the sell‑off is almost complete, leaving a vacuum that can be filled by a surprise catalyst.

whats_happening_now.attention_check: Google Trends for the ticker is flat – there is no public interest. This is a perfect setup for a contrarian play because the market has not yet priced in any potential upside.

near_term_catalysts: A positive update from one of the funded projects (e.g., a feasibility study or a first‑time production milestone).
A change in commodity prices that makes the projects more attractive.
Any sign of a new investor or partnership that could bring additional capital.
A sharp uptick in trading volume that could indicate short covering.
expect_next.watch_for: Look for a daily close above the current low with a volume spike, and any news that confirms a project milestone or new investment.
expect_next.timing_regime: We are likely in the late‑stage washout of a deep crash – the price has already fallen through most of the way and is waiting for a catalyst to trigger a rebound.

buy_vs_sell.lean: Contrarian Bullish – the stock is a deep crash that has reached a point where the market is exhausted. If a catalyst appears, the compressed price swing could deliver a strong rebound.
buy_vs_sell.bull_case: Historically, a deep crash (our signal color is GREEN – roughly 70‑85% drop) has produced an average 39% bounce. If the price recovers 50% from the current level, that would double the position. The market has already shed most of its fear, so a small catalyst can unlock a large upside.
buy_vs_sell.bear_case: The main downside is a potential liquidity issue – if the company cannot raise more capital or if a project stalls, the price could stay flat or fall a little more. The worst case is a 20% further drop, but most of the 70‑85% decline is already gone.
buy_vs_sell.risk_reward: Risk 20% down vs Reward 100% up = 1:5 asymmetry. Even a modest recovery delivers a very attractive payoff.

playbook.if_bullish: Enter now with a 25% position. Use a tight stop just below the recent low to protect against a brief retracement. Add on if volume confirms a breakout and the price closes above the low on a higher day.
playbook.if_watching: Hold until you see a clear catalyst – a project update, a new investor, or a volume spike. Do not trade on vague speculation; wait for a concrete signal that the project is moving forward.
playbook.if_passing: Skip this one if you see any signs of regulatory or liquidity risk that could prevent the company from delivering on its projects. Otherwise, the deep crash and dead sentiment give a strong contrarian case.

ai_insights.bottom_line: Deep crash with a silent market and fresh capital injections – classic contrarian play with a 1:5 risk/reward potential.
